Nevertheless, the absence of reaction kinetics in this process imposes limitations on the reactor design and process optimization. By combining Density Functional Theory and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, the reaction kinetics were systematically studied. The critical oxygen concentration of the reaction system was calculated, and the feed molar ratio of oxygen was determined to be 8 %. The feed molar ratio of acetic acid was set to be 16 % to keep higher turnover frequency of allyl acetate and lower energy consumption. The preferential formation route of allyl acetate was obtained and the turnover frequency and space-time yield of allyl acetate were calculated. The apparent activation energy was determined to be 62.35 kJ⋅mol-1. Finally, the reaction kinetic equation was derived and the kinetic parameters were obtained by fitting the data of space-time yield. This work provides theoretical guidance for reactor design and technological process improvement on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. Of particular significance is the contribution of a novel approach to the acquisition of reaction kinetic equations, which has a good application prospect. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Allyl acetate PdCu catalysts Density functional theory Kinetic monte carlo Reaction kinetics Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Allyl acetate (CH3COOCH2CHCH2) is an important intermediate in organic synthesis, of which widespread utilization in a multitude of industrial applications encompasses the production of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, spices, surfactants, silicon coupling agents, resin modifiers, and cross-linking agents, etc. [1–5]. Among them, allyl alcohol and its derivatives are the most important downstream uses of allyl acetate [6,7]. Allyl alcohol is a significant chemical raw material. Its molecular structure contains two functional groups of C = C bond and hydroxyl group, which enables it to participate in a variety of chemical reactions, including oxidation, reduction, esterification and addition, and synthesize a series of widely used downstream products. Its versatility extends to a wide range of applications in fields as diverse as agricultural chemistry, medicine, spices and organic synthesis [8–10]. The downstream products of allyl alcohol principally comprise 1,4-butanediol (BDO), epichlorohydrin, glycerol and various allyl ethers, allyl compounds containing N/S, allyl ester polymer monomers, and so forth. Among them, BDO is a fundamental organic chemical and fine chemical raw material, which can be used to produce tetrahydrofuran (THF), polyurethane (PU), γ-butyrolactone (GBL), poly (butylene succinate) (PBS), poly (butylene terephthalate) (PBT), N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP), etc. Its widespread applications are evident in diverse fields, including medicine, the chemical industry, textiles, papermaking, the automobile industry, and the daily chemical industry. It is noteworthy that BDO occupies a pivotal role in economic development [11–15]. Moreover, in anticipation of the proclamation of the national plastic restriction order, there has been an observed increase in demand for degradable plastics within markets. BDO, a pivotal raw material in the production of degradable plastics such as PBS and PBAT, is experiencing favorable market conditions. The production processes of BDO mainly consists of Lyondell method, Reppe method, Mitsubishi method, maleic anhydride direct hydrogenation and maleic anhydride esterification hydrogenation [16]. The Lyondell method is a process that utilizes allyl alcohol as the primary raw material, which has the advantages of low investment, low energy consumption, recyclable catalyst, long service life, safe reaction, high utilization value of by-products, liquid-phase reaction of hydroformylation and hydrogenation, and easy adjustment of production load. These factors combine to make the Lyondell method a promising process. In addition, as an important raw material for allyl acetate, propylene currently has the problem of overcapacity. In addition to the production of polypropylene, butyl alcohol, acrylonitrile, propylene oxide, acrylic acid and other conventional bulk chemical products, it is imperative to seek more downstream products, adjust the industrial structure and optimize the industrial chain. Propylene undergoes acetoxylation to yield allyl acetate, which in turn is converted into allyl alcohol and a range of derivative products. These processes have the potential to address the current overcapacity of propylene to a certain extent. Taking propylene as raw material, allyl acetate is prepared through the acetoxylation reaction to further produce allyl alcohol and a series of derivatives, which will alleviate the current situation of propylene overcapacity to a certain extent. The reaction equation for the formation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene is shown as follows. It is noteworthy that this reaction can be executed in either the liquid phase or the gas phase. (1) C3H6+CH3COOH+0.5O2→CH3COOCH2CHCH2 +H2O The process of allyl acetate production by liquid phase method is accompanied by certain issues, including low selectivity, high reaction pressure (1–7MPaA), strong corrosive medium, complex catalyst system and frequent regeneration (PdCl2, Pd(CH3COO)2 and other Pd salts). Consequently, the process has not yet achieved industrial application [17–21]. The current mainstream process for the production of allyl acetate is the gas phase method, in which propylene, acetic acid and oxygen are acetoxylated in a tubular fixed-bed reactor loaded with Pd-based catalysts under the conditions of 433.15–453.15 K and 0.6–1.1MPaA. In general, Pd and its salts or complexes are the most effective catalysts for acetoxylation. Moreover, the incorporation of additional metal compounds into the Pd catalyst has been shown to enhance the selectivity of the target products, particularly in the presence of Cu [22]. Further advancements have revealed that the PdCu catalyst has the capacity to enhance the selectivity and space-time yield of allyl acetate. In addition, it can reduce the economic burden associated with Pd utilization in industrial processes [23]. This finding has been documented in the patents of Sinopec, Showa Denko and other companies [24–33]. Nevertheless, the reaction kinetics of the process is unknown, which limited the optimization of reaction conditions, reactor design and technological process improvement to a great extent. Reactor is the key equipment in the production unit of allyl acetate, and its scale-up design is one of the core problems, which requires the reaction kinetic equation used to describe the industrial-scale reactor. The reaction kinetic equation is usually obtained by laboratory measurement, after strict model screening, experimental determination and data analysis, which has certain limitations. This is because the industrial-scale reactor is very different from the laboratory reactor in terms of size, which may lead to a large error between the experimental reaction kinetics equation and the actual reactor operation data in terms of predicting reactor performance, and is not suitable for industrial-scale reactor design and development. Microscopically, Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations reveal the formation and breaking of chemical bonds [34–38]. On the mesoscopic scale, kinetic Monte Carlo (kMC) simulations provide a detailed explanation of the interaction between all elementary processes in the catalytic process, thus offering insight into the overall control of the catalytic process at different scales [39–43]. Hansen et al. [44,45]. firstly combined kMC and DFT, which has become a multi-scale simulation framework for studying the mechanism and kinetics of surface-interface catalytic reactions. In this study, based on the main reaction mechanism of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts by DFT calculations [46], the activation energy and pre-exponential factor of each elementary reaction in the main reaction network were obtained. Next, the oxygen concentration and the appropriate molar ratio of acetic acid in the system of acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate were calculated. Then, the preferential formation route of allyl acetate was obtained. Subsequently, the turnover frequency (TOF) and space-time yield (STY) of allyl acetate were calculated. Utilizing these calculations, the apparent activation energy of the main reaction was determined. Finally, the kinetics of the main reaction was studied. The reaction kinetics equation was derived by using the two assumptions of steady state approximation and rate-determining step, and the kinetic parameters were obtained by fitting the data of STY. 2 Computational details 2.1 DFT calculations and data summary For the PdCu catalyst used in acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate, the content of Pd is higher than that of Cu, and the molar ratio of Pd to Cu is usually about 3 [33,47,48]. Therefore, the Pd3Cu lattice cell was firstly constructed, which is similar to pure Pd and Cu lattice cells in that it is a face-centered cubic crystal [49]. And the (111) facet is the most stable surface for the fcc crystal [50–52]. The bulk lattice constants were calculated to be 3.867 Å, which is consistent with the calculated value of 3.891 Å [53,54]. Besides, the formation energy of Pd3Cu lattice cell was calculated to be −0.304 eV, which shows that the Pd3Cu alloy can exist stably [46]. Then, to select the most suitable model for PdCu catalyst, several models with various amounts of Cu surface segregation were evaluated, as illustrated in Figure A1. It was established that for PdCu bimetallic catalysts, the presence of Cu atoms increases the electron cloud density of Pd atoms, causes the d-band center of Pd atoms to move up, and increases the dispersion of Pd atoms [46], which is in accordance with the observation that the top atomic layer of the PdCu catalyst is rich in Cu, while the near surface region is rich in Pd [55,56]. And Pd atoms on the top atomic layer are surrounded by Cu atoms and tend to be dispersed as isolated monomers [55,57–59]. With the increase of the segregation degree of Cu atoms and the dispersion degree of Pd atoms, the catalytic activity of Pd atoms is continuously improved [46]. Hence, the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model was selected to represent the PdCu catalysts for the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate. At present, the main reaction mechanism of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model has been studied. The main reaction network is shown in Figure A2; the Gibbs reaction energy (G r) and Gibbs activation energy (G a) of each elementary reaction are enumerated in Table A1 and the initial state, transition state, and final state images of each elementary step are shown in Figure A3 [46]. In this work, the Gibbs free energy is calculated by eq (2): (2) G = E + Z P E + H − T S Where G is the Gibbs free energy; E is the electronic energy; ZPE represents the zero-point energy correction; H represents the thermal correction to enthalpy; T represents the temperature; S represents the entropy and the PV contribution to translation for adsorbed molecules is neglected [60]. The Gibbs reaction energy ( G r ) and activation energy ( G a ) were calculated by eq (3) and eq (4), respectively. (3) G r = G F S − G I S (4) G a = G T S − G I S Where G I S , G T S and G F S are the Gibbs free energy of related initial states (IS), transition states (TS) and final sates (FS), respectively. 2.2 kMC simulations In kMC simulations, the Variable Step Size Method (VSSM) and the Lattice-gas Model were utilized[61]. A two-dimensional periodic model with 128 × 128 lattice points was constructed to represent the catalyst surface, which corresponds to the PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface model in DFT calculation with the same active sites. The surface models employed in DFT calculations and kMC simulations are illustrated in Fig. 1 . The lattice-gas model provides a comprehensive definition of all species involved in the acetoxylation of propylene, including CH3COOH*, CH3CHCH2*, O2*, CH3COO*, CH2CHCH2*, O*, CH3COOCH2CHCH2*, H2O*, etc. Kinetic parameters are indispensable input data for kMC simulations, and the detailed calculation methods are displayed in the following formulas. According to the collision theory, the adsorption rate constant is calculated from eq (5) [62]. (5) k ads = σ 1 P A site 2 π m k B T Where P denotes the partial pressure (Pa) of adsorbate in the gas phase; A site is the area of an adsorption site; σ 1 is the adhesion coefficient, which is set to 1 [43,63–68]; m is the mass (kg) of an adsorbate molecule; k B is Boltzmann constant; T is the temperature (K). The reaction rate constant is calculated by Transition State Theory (TST) [69]. (6) k = ν exp ( − E a R T ) Where ν is pre-exponential factor; R is the ideal gas constant; T is the reaction temperature (K) and E a is the energy difference between transition state and initial state corrected by ZPE correction. The pre-exponential factor ν is calculated as follows [70,71]. (7) ν = ∏ i = 1 3 n ν i I S ∏ i = 1 3 n − 1 ν i T S Where ν i I S is the vibrational frequency of initial state; ν i T S is the vibrational frequency of transition state (excluding the imaginary frequency); n is the number of atoms of the reactant (adsorbate). The rate constant of gas desorption is defined as [43]: (8) k d e s = k a d s K e q = k a d s e x p ( − G g a s − G a d s k B T ) Where K e q represents the equilibrium constant; G g a s and G a d s are the Gibbs free energies for gaseous and adsorbed species. In this work, G g a s and G a d s of related species are listed in Table A2 in Supplementary material. The reaction network for kMC simulations encompasses the adsorption and desorption of reactants, the desorption of products, surface reactions and surface diffusion. The calculation results of the kinetic parameters for each elemental process are displayed in Table 1 . For the surface reactions, the symbol “↔” denotes the simultaneous consideration of both positive and reverse reactions in the simulations. E a,f and E a,r represent the activation energy of the positive reaction and reverse reaction, respectively; ν 0,f and ν 0,r are the pre-exponential factors of the positive reaction and reverse reaction, respectively. The diffusion of O* and OH* are mainly considered in the surface diffusion, which are the main intermediates on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface. In order to reduce the error caused by the randomness of kMC simulations, each task was simulated three times. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Critical oxygen concentration In actual industrial production, the oxygen content of combustible gases is a critical parameter for monitoring and control. In this regard, the safety limit of oxygen content of the combustible gases in the process of preparing allyl acetate by the acetoxylation of propylene was calculated, that is, the critical oxygen concentration, to determine the feed mole fraction of oxygen in the process. In this system, the combustible gas is the binary mixture of propylene and acetic acid, and the explosion limit of the two in air is shown in Table 2 . The lower explosion limit of combustible gas in pure oxygen is approximately equivalent to that in air, which can be approximately regarded as the same value. The upper explosion limit L 2 of combustible gas in pure oxygen is calculated by eq (9) [72]. (9) L 2 = L 1 + 70 × ( lo g 10 ( 100 − L 1 ) − 1.321 ) Where L 1 is the upper explosion limit of combustible gas in air. The calculated explosion limits of propylene and acetic acid in pure oxygen are shown in Table 2. In the production process of allyl acetate, propylene is typically present in excess compared to acetic acid. Referring to different allyl acetate production processes [32,73,74], the feed mole fraction of propylene is set to 45 %. Considering the feed molar fraction of acetic acid as 10 % - 20 %, the explosion limit of the mixture of propylene and acetic acid in air or oxygen was calculated by Le Chatlier rule. (10) L = 100 V A L A + V B L B + V C L C + · · · · · · Where L is the upper or lower explosion limit of mixed combustible gas in air or pure oxygen; L A, L B and L C are the upper or lower explosion limits of each combustible gas in air or pure oxygen; V A, V B and V C are the volume fractions of each combustible gas in the mixture. The calculated explosion limits for the binary mixture of propylene and acetic acid in air as well as in pure oxygen are shown in Table 3 . Subsequently, the explosive ternary diagrams of the mixture of propylene and acetic acid, oxygen, and nitrogen are plotted, as shown in Fig. 2 . The vertices F, O and N are the mixture of propylene and acetic acid, oxygen and nitrogen, respectively. The straight line between the explosion range and the vertex F is the air line, and the starting point of the air line in the line ON is at the O2 concentration of 20.95 % (A); L 2 and U 2 are the lower and upper explosion limits of the mixture of propylene and acetic acid in pure oxygen. L 1 and U 1 represent the lower and upper explosion limits of the mixture of propylene and acetic acid in air. Initially, U 1 and U 2 are connected, and subsequently, L 1 and L 2 are connected to extend the two lines, and the intersection point is L. Finally, a tangent parallel to FN is made through L, and the intersection with ON is the critical oxygen concentration (COC), which is illustrated in Table 3. With reference to these values, the feed mole fraction of oxygen in the process of preparing allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene can be determined. In this work, the feed molar fraction of oxygen was set to 8 %. 3.2 Effect of acetic acid It has been determined that the feed mole fraction of propylene is 45 % and the feed mole fraction of oxygen is 8 %. It is necessary to further clarify the feed molar fraction of acetic acid. The single conversion of acetic acid in this process is approximately 18 % and the unreacted acetic acid must be separated by distillation and subsequently returned to the acetoxylation reactor for recycling. Therefore, the relationship between the feed mole fraction of acetic acid and the formation rate of allyl acetate was studied. The reaction temperature was set to 443.15 K, the reaction pressure was set to 0.8, 0.9 and 1.0MPaA, and the feed mole fraction of acetic acid was set to 10 %, 12 %, 14 %, 16 %, 18 % and 20 %. The simulation results are displayed in Fig. 3 . It can be found that under the set conditions, the TOF of allyl acetate increases with the increase of the feed mole fraction of acetic acid. Moreover, when the feed molar fraction of acetic acid is higher than 16 %, the increase in the TOF of allyl acetate becomes smaller and smaller. At this time, if the feed molar fraction of acetic acid continues to increase, although the TOF of allyl acetate will increase, the degree of increase has been greatly reduced, resulting in a decrease in the conversion of acetic acid. More acetic acid that is not involved in the reaction needs to be first separated and purified by distillation operation, and then sent back to the acetoxylation reactor for recycling, resulting in a significant increase in energy consumption. Consequently, the feed molar fraction of acetic acid was determined to be 16 %. 3.3 The acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate The main reaction of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate under varying conditions was analyzed. The temperature was varied between 433.15 K and 453.15 K, whilst the pressure was maintained at 0.6–1.1MPaA. The analysis of the data was performed using steady-state data. Under the given reaction conditions such as temperature and pressure, the simulations took a long enough time to make the system reach a steady state. The TOF of each elementary process was collected from all data points over a period of time after reaching the steady state and averaged as the corresponding value under the reaction conditions to reduce the influence of statistical small fluctuations on the results. Firstly, the preferential formation route of allyl acetate under typical reaction conditions was obtained by kMC simulations. Next, the TOF and STY of allyl acetate were counted. Subsequently, the apparent activation energy of the main reaction was calculated. Finally, based on the preferential formation route of allyl acetate, the reaction kinetics equation was derived by using the two assumptions of steady state approximation and rate-determining step, and the kinetic parameters were obtained by fitting the data of STY. 3.3.1 The preferential formation route of allyl acetate The simulation results of the reaction temperature of 443.15 K and the reaction pressure of 1.10MPaA are analyzed, in order to determine the preferential formation route of allyl acetate. In the formation process of allyl acetate, the TOF of related elementary process is shown in Fig. 4 . The blue number in Fig. 4 represents the TOF value of each elementary process, and the width of the green arrow for each elementary process is proportional to the TOF value. It can be found that allyl acetate is mainly formed by the adsorption of reactants, the surface reaction of related species and the desorption of products. The related elementary processes are listed in Table 4 . A1, A2 and A3 are the adsorption processes of oxygen, propylene and acetic acid on PdCu3/Pd3Cu(111) surface, respectively. R1 is the dissociation reaction of O2* on the surface of the catalyst to generate two molecules of activated O*. R3 is the oxygen-assisted dehydrogenation reaction of CH3COOH*, generating activated CH3COO* and OH*, while R7 is the oxygen-assisted dehydrogenation reaction of CH3CHCH2*, producing activated CH2CHCH2* and OH*. Subsequently, the activated CH3COO* and CH2CHCH2* undergo CO coupling reaction (R15) to form adsorbed allyl acetate. Finally, 98.60 % of the adsorbed allyl acetate was desorbed to produce the gas phase product allyl acetate. In this process, the CO coupling reaction of CH3COO* and CH2CHCH2* (R15) is the rate-determining step, with the largest Gibbs activation energy and the smallest reaction rate. 3.3.2 TOF and STY of allyl acetate The temperature was set at 433.15K-453.15 K (one data point per 5 K), the pressure was 0.6–1.1MPaA (one data point per 0.1MPaA), the feed mole fractions of propylene, acetic acid and oxygen were 45 %, 16 % and 8 %, respectively, and water with mole fraction of 2 % was introduced to obtain the TOF of allyl acetate, as shown in Table 5 . As demonstrated in Table 5, an increase in temperature results in a corresponding increase in the formation rate of allyl acetate, under constant pressure conditions. It has been established that an increase in temperature from 433.15 K to 453.15 K typically results in a doubling of TOF of allyl acetate. When the temperature is constant, the formation rate of allyl acetate increases with the increase of pressure. The simulation results of TOF were converted into STY and then compared with the patent data related to allyl acetate. STY is defined as the amount of the product obtained per unit volume (or mass) of the catalyst per unit time, under given reaction conditions. And the relationship between STY and TOF can be expressed by eq (11). (11) S T Y = T O F · M A A N A · D · w t Pd · N A M P d · 3600 Where N A is Avogadro constant (6.20 × 1023 mol-1); M AA is the molar mass of allyl acetate (g⋅mol-1); M Pd is the molar mass of Pd (g⋅mol-1); D is the dispersion of Pd atoms in the PdCu catalyst; ωt Pd is the Pd content (g⋅L-1) of the PdCu catalyst. In the study conducted by Liu et al., the Pd content (ωt Pd) of the PdCu catalyst was 3.0 g⋅L-1. The dispersion (D) of Pd atoms in the PdCu catalyst was set to be 31.1 % [75]. Based on this, STY of allyl acetate under different conditions in this work was calculated as shown in Table 6 , which is in good agreement with the results of Liu, with the highest STY of 415 g⋅Lcat -1⋅h-1 [76]. 3.3.3 The apparent activation energy As demonstrated in eq (12), a correlation can be established between TOF and the apparent activation energy [77]. (12) T O F = k ( T ) · f ( p j ) = A · exp ( − E a a p p R T ) · f ( p j ) Where TOF represents the turnover frequency of related products, k ( T ) denotes the temperature-dependent term, f ( p j ) signifies the pressure-dependent term, A is the pre-exponential factor and E a a p p is the apparent activation energy. The apparent activation energy in a specific temperature range can be approximated by plotting the natural logarithm of TOF (LNTOF) to the reciprocal of temperature (1/T). As demonstrated in Fig. 5 , the Arrhenius plot for allyl acetate formation with the temperature of 433.15 to 453.15 K under different pressures have been plotted. In addition, the linear fitting results of LN(TOF) and 1/T are enumerated in Fig. 5. It was found that the correlation coefficient R2 under varying pressures all exceeds 0.97, thereby indicating a good fitting effect. The slope (α) of the fitting results under different pressures was counted and averaged as the slope of LN(TOF) and 1/T linear fitting curve in the range of 433.15–453.15 K and 0.6–1.1MPaA, as illustrated in Table 7 . The relationship between the slope (α) and the apparent activation energy ( E a a p p ) is shown in eq (13). (13) α = − E a a p p R On this basis, the apparent activation energy for the preparation of allyl acetate by the acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalysts in the range of 433.15–453.15 K, 0.6–1.0MPaA was calculated to be 62.35 kJ⋅mol-1. 3.3.4 The reaction kinetics equation Heterogeneous catalytic reaction is a multi-step process, including adsorption, desorption and surface reaction. According to the preferential formation route of allyl acetate obtained in Section 3.3.1, combined with the two assumptions of steady state approximation and rate-determining step, the reaction kinetics equation for the formation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalyst was derived. If the reaction process reaches a steady state, the concentration of the intermediate compound does not change with time, which is the steady state approximation hypothesis. Furthermore, the slowest step in the reaction is regarded as the rate-determining step, and its rate is expressed as the reaction rate of the chemical reaction comprising the reaction step. The remaining reaction steps, with the exception of rate-determining step, are approximated to be at equilibrium. Steady state approximation and rate-determining step are two important concepts in the derivation of reaction kinetics equations. In this work, it is necessary to clarify the formation path of water in order to derive the reaction kinetics equation for the formation of allyl acetate by the acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalyst. The kMC simulation results indicate that water is predominantly produced by the OH* disproportionation reaction, and the associated elementary process is delineated in Table 8 . In consideration of the preferential formation routes of allyl acetate (Table 4) and water (Table 8), the formula (14–24) is obtained with the two assumptions of steady state approximation and rate-determining step. Eq (19-21) and (23) represent the surface reaction R1, R3, R7 and R22 to reach equilibrium, respectively. Eq (22) represents the rate of surface reaction R15. Since R15 is the rate-determining step, eq (22) is also the reaction kinetic equation for the formation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalyst. Besides, the surface coverage of all adsorbed species can be expressed by θ V , as demonstrated in eq (25-33), derived from eq (14-23). Afterwards, θ V is calculated by employing eq (24), as demonstrated in eq (34). (34) θ V = 1 / ( 1 + K o 2 P o 2 + K H A c P H A c + K C 3 H 6 P C 3 H 6 + K H 2 O P H 2 O + K A A P A A + ( K 1 K o 2 P o 2 ) 0.5 + K 1 0.25 K 5 − 0.5 K o 2 0.25 K H 2 O 0.5 P o 2 0.25 P H 2 O 0.5 + K 1 0.25 K 2 K 5 0.5 K C 3 H 6 K o 2 0.25 K H 2 O − 0.5 P C 3 H 6 P o 2 0.25 P H 2 O − 0.5 + K 1 0.25 K 3 K 5 0.5 K H A c K o 2 0.25 K H 2 O − 0.5 P H A c P o 2 0.25 P H 2 O − 0.5 ) Based on the above derivation, the reaction kinetic equation for the formation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalyst can be expressed as eq (35). (35) r = k 4 K 1 0.5 K 2 K 3 K 5 K C 3 H 6 K H A c K o 2 0.5 K H 2 O ⋅ P C 3 H 6 P H A c P o 2 0.5 P H 2 O ⋅ θ V 2 The denominator of eq (35) represents the adsorption term, indicating which species are adsorbed on the surface of catalyst and their adsorption strength. The coverage of key species at 443.15 K and 1.1MPaA are shown in Fig. 6 . For the species CH3COOH*, CH3COO*, CH2CHCH2*, CH3COOCH2CHCH2*, and H2O*, their corresponding terms in the denominator of eq (35) can be ignored due to their low coverage. Meanwhile, the equilibrium constants of each term in the denominator of eq (35) are combined to obtain the simplified equation: (36) r = k P C 3 H 6 P H A c P o 2 0.5 P H 2 O − 1 ( 1 + K A P C 3 H 6 + K B P o 2 + K C P o 2 0.5 + K D P o 2 0.25 P H 2 O 0.5 ) 2 Where k = k 4 K 1 0.5 K 2 K 3 K 5 K C 3 H 6 K H A c K o 2 0.5 K H 2 O , is the reaction rate constant, which is a function of temperature, and can be expressed in the form of the Arrhenius equation, as shown in eq (37); K A = K C 3 H 6 ; K B = K o 2 ; K C = ( K 1 K o 2 ) 0.5 and K D = K 1 0.25 K 5 − 0.5 K o 2 0.25 K H 2 O 0.5 . (37) k = A e − E a R T In eq (37), A is the pre-exponential factor; E a is the apparent activation energy of the formation of allyl acetate, which has been calculated to be 62,350 J⋅mol-1 in the previous section. Finally, the parameters in eq (36) were fitted by using STY of allyl acetate under different conditions in Table 6, which are listed in Table 9 . Mean Relative Error (MRE) was calculated to evaluate the fitting results, which is the average value of the relative difference between the predicted value and the actual value, and the calculation formula is shown in eq (A1). MRE was calculated to be 3.68 %. Additionally, Goodness of Fit is defined as the degree to which the regression curve aligns with the actual values and the statistical measure is the coefficient of determination (R2), which indicates the degree to which the model explains the total variation of the target variable. The value of R2 ranges from 0 to 1, and a value closer to 1 signifies a stronger explanatory power of the model. The calculation formula is shown in eq (A2-A4). R2 of the fitting result of the reaction kinetic equation for the formation of allyl acetate by acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalyst is calculated to be 0.975, indicating a good fitting effect. 4 Conclusion In this work, the reaction kinetics of the acetoxylation of propylene to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts were systematically studied by combining DFT and kMC simulations on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. Firstly, based on the main reaction mechanism of propylene acetoxylation to allyl acetate on PdCu catalysts by DFT calculations, the activation energy and pre-exponential factor of each elementary reaction in the main reaction network were obtained. Next, the critical oxygen concentration of the mixture of propylene and acetic acid in the reaction system was calculated, and the feed molar ratio of oxygen was determined to be 8 %. Then, the feed molar ratio of acetic acid was set to be 16 % to keep higher turnover frequency of allyl acetate and lower energy consumption. Furthermore, the preferential formation route of allyl acetate was obtained. Acetic acid and propylene are activated by the O-assisted dehydrogenation reaction to form CH3COO* and CH2CHCH2*, respectively. And allyl acetate is generated by the CO coupling of CH3COO* and CH2CHCH2*. The TOF and STY of allyl acetate under different conditions were calculated. Based on these, the apparent activation energy was determined to be 62.35 kJ⋅mol-1. Finally, the reaction kinetic equation was derived and the kinetic parameters were obtained by fitting the data of STY. It's hoped that this work will provide a new idea for obtaining the reaction kinetic equation for the heterogeneous catalytic reaction. coredata.dc:description: Allyl acetate is a vital intermediate in organic synthesis, which is produced by the acetoxylation of propylene on PdCu catalysts and mainly used for the synthesis of allyl alcohol and a range of derivatives, including 1,4-butanediol. Nevertheless, the absence of reaction kinetics in this process imposes limitations on the reactor design and process optimization. By combining Density Functional Theory and kinetic Monte Carlo simulations, the reaction kinetics were systematically studied. The critical oxygen concentration of the reaction system was calculated, and the feed molar ratio of oxygen was determined to be 8 %. The feed molar ratio of acetic acid was set to be 16 % to keep higher turnover frequency of allyl acetate and lower energy consumption. The preferential formation route of allyl acetate was obtained and the turnover frequency and space-time yield of allyl acetate were calculated. The apparent activation energy was determined to be 62.35 kJ⋅mol-1. Finally, the reaction kinetic equation was derived and the kinetic parameters were obtained by fitting the data of space-time yield. This work provides theoretical guidance for reactor design and technological process improvement on microscopic and mesoscopic scales. Of particular significance is the contribution of a novel approach to the acquisition of reaction kinetic equations, which has a good application prospect.
